title: 107_hr1509
content: The Act titled "National Media Campaign to Prevent Underage Drinking Act of 2001" amends the Public Health Service Act to establish a national media campaign aimed at preventing underage drinking. The Secretary is required to conduct a national media campaign to reduce and prevent underage drinking in the United States. The campaign will be based on scientific research and will supplement existing efforts by various entities. The Secretary is mandated to conduct a national media campaign targeting underage drinking in the United States, collaborating with various federal agencies and departments. Funds will be allocated for advertising efforts focusing on prevention and treatment resources in specific geographic areas, with culturally competent messages for minority groups. The Secretary must allocate funds for the national media campaign to meet its reach and frequency goals. The funds can only be used for campaign development, media purchase, talent payments, production costs, testing, evaluation, and fees for the winning bidder. The Assistant Secretary for Health can use funds for partnerships with various groups and collaborations with the entertainment industry to create underage-drinking prevention messages in different media formats. Prohibitions include not supplanting community-based efforts. The Assistant Secretary for Health can use funds for partnerships and collaborations with the entertainment industry to create underage-drinking prevention messages in various media formats. Prohibitions include not supplanting community-based efforts, pro bono public service time donated by broadcasting networks, partisan political purposes, featuring elected officials in media campaigns, or supporting advertising with company logos. The Secretary requires sellers of media time or space for the national campaign to provide non-Federal contributions equal to 50% of the purchase price, which can be funds or in-kind contributions. A comprehensive strategy on underage drinking prevention must be developed and submitted to Congress within 6 months, outlining goals, target audiences, message points, and evaluation plans. The Secretary must provide annual reports to Congress on the activities and costs of the national media campaign, including progress reports based on measurable outcomes. The term 'underage drinking' is defined as the consumption of alcohol by individuals below the legal purchasing age in the state. Funding for the campaign requires non-Federal contributions equal to 50% of the purchase price from sellers of media time or space. Funding for the national media campaign on underage drinking requires non-Federal contributions equal to 50% of the purchase price from sellers of media time or space. Authorization of appropriations is necessary for fiscal years 2002 through 2007, with a limitation of $1,000,000 for subsection (c)(1) activities.
